questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of increasing shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough. She has been unable to perform her daily activities. She has also had malaise and bilateral ankle pain during this period. She first noticed the symptoms after returning from a vacation to Arizona. She is a research assistant at the university's geology laboratory. She was born in Nigeria and visits her family there twice a year; her last trip was 3 months ago. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is no palpable cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Examination shows ciliary injection and photophobia of the left eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's x-ray findings in conjunction with shortness of breath, dry cough, and constitutional symptoms (e.g., malaise) strongly suggest sarcoidosis. This condition most commonly affects the lungs; however, sarcoidosis is a multisystem disorder that can manifest in many other organs. Extrapulmonary manifestations include anterior uveitis (suggested by this patient's photophobia and ciliary injections), which occurs in approx. 25% of patients. The triad of symmetric arthritis (which is often migratory), erythema nodosum, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is referred to as Lofgren syndrome, which is a form of acute sarcoidosis. Acute sarcoidosis is usually self-limited, resolving within approx. 2 years, and rarely progresses to chronic sarcoidosis.

Incidence is highest among women and Black individuals.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient comes from a geographic area where tuberculosis (TB) is endemic. Pulmonary TB also manifests with dyspnea, malaise, lymphadenopathy, and cough, but the cough would normally be productive in TB. Hilar lymphadenopathy is a common feature seen on x-ray in TB, but reticular opacities would not be expected. TB would rather cause a calcified granuloma (Ghon complex). Lastly, even though TB can affect the skeleton (primarily the spine), ankle arthralgia is extremely uncommon in TB.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis may manifest with worsening dyspnea, nonproductive cough, malaise, and reticular opacities on chest x-ray. However, arthralgia and hilar lymphadenopathy are typically not seen in hypersensitivity pneumonitis. The absence of a history of occupational and/or environmental exposure to certain allergens also makes a different diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

CT chest (inspiratory phase; axial plane; lung window) of a patient with hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP)

An irregular reticular pattern of fibrosis predominates in the subpleural regions of the mid zones of the lungs. A small amount of honeycombing (example indicated by red overlay) is seen. There is a heterogeneous pattern of lung attenuation (mosaic attenuation), with areas of low attenuation (examples indicated by green overlays) in some regions with no fibrosis; expiratory phase imaging could help assess whether or not such areas represent air trapping.

Fibrotic HP has a variable appearance on CT. A pattern typical of fibrotic HP shows a random axial distribution of coarse reticulation and small airway disease with minimal honeycombing and no zonal predominance. Subpleural fibrosis can be compatible with HP, as can upper zonal, lower zonal, or central predominant distributions.

D) INCORRECT:

Hilar lymphadenopathy, nonproductive cough, dyspnea, and malaise may be initial signs of Hodgkin lymphoma. However, the absence of B symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, night sweats) and lymphadenopathy in other sites (e.g., axillary and cervical nodes), as well as the presence of a normal complete blood count and arthralgia (not typically associated with Hodgkin lymphoma) suggest a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Histoplasmosis may manifest with dyspnea, nonproductive cough, malaise, and hilar lymphadenopathy. Arthralgia may also be present in about 5–10% of cases. However, this patient does not come from an endemic area (e.g., Ohio, Mississippi) and does not have a history of exposure to bats or birds (e.g., cave exploration). Additionally, anterior uveitis would not be expected. The history of travel to Africa might suggest a risk of African histoplasmosis caused by Histoplasma duboisii. However, African histoplasmosis typically manifests only as skin and bone disease without pulmonary involvement.

F) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) may manifest with cough, dyspnea, malaise, and arthralgias. However, the absence of upper respiratory tract disease (e.g., sinusitis, otitis media) and renal disease suggests a different diagnosis. Moreover, hilar lymphadenopathy is typically absent in patients with GPA.
questions.hint: Reticular opacities and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy are visible on this patient's chest x-ray.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a dry cough and worsening shortness of breath with exertion for the past 6 months. She used to go running three times each week but had to stop because of decreased exercise tolerance and pain in the bilateral ankles. Two months ago, she was in Nigeria for several weeks to visit her family. She is allergic to cats and pollen. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 17 years. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple 1.5- to 2-cm, nontender lymph nodes in the axillae. A few crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. Her serum calcium concentration is 11.7 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows hilar enlargement bilaterally and reticular opacities in both upper lungs. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Necrotizing inflammation is seen in a variety of conditions, including tuberculosis (TB). Patients with TB often present with a cough, shortness of breath, hypercalcemia, and hilar lymphadenopathy on chest x-ray. Furthermore, this patient's recent trip to Nigeria, a high-risk country, should raise concern for TB. However, TB generally manifests with a productive cough and is likely accompanied by fever, weight loss, and night sweats. Additionally, TB does not explain this patient's arthritis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of pulmonary tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

An abundance of leukocytes is visible in the center of the image. The immune cells appear to form circular patterns enclosing extracellular matrix. Necrotic pulmonary tissue is visible on the right border.

These findings are consistent with pulmonary tuberculosis.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) CORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation resulting in noncaseating granulomas is the hallmark of sarcoidosis. T-cell dysfunction and increased B-cell activity lead to local immune hyperactivity, inflammation, and subsequent formation of noncaseating granulomas. The lung and the lymphatic system are most commonly affected, although sarcoidosis is a systemic disorder that can affect any organ. In sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases, the expression of 1α-hydroxylase is increased in macrophages. This enzyme hydroxylates 25-hydroxyvitamin D to its active form, which results in chronic, increased calcium resorption.

Other granulomatous diseases include tuberculosis, pneumoconiosis, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's pulmonary symptoms (cough, shortness of breath) combined with a smoking history is compatible with a pulmonary neoplasm, which cannot be definitively ruled out without further diagnostic imaging in this case. However, the combination of this patient's x-ray findings, axillary lymphadenopathy, history of arthritis of both ankles, and her relatively young age makes sarcoidosis more likely than a pulmonary neoplasm.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (A: PA view) and CT chest (B: coronal plane; lung window) of a patient with pulmonary adenocarcinoma

A spiculated nodule is seen in the upper lobe of the right lung (white arrows).

RULB = Right upper lobe bronchus

D) INCORRECT:

Certain viral infections, such as atypical pneumonia, may manifest similarly to what is seen in this patient (e.g. nonproductive cough, dyspnea, auscultatory crackles). However, viral infections often manifest with additional features such as a low-grade fever, headaches, and sore throat. In addition, a viral infection fails to explain hypercalcemia and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a female patient with a history of atypical pneumonia

Opacities are distributed bilaterally, predominantly in the upper lobes. Some of the opacities appear linear (examples indicated by red overlay), while others appear nodular (examples indicated by white arrowheads). Areas of confluent opacification (example indicated by green overlay) are also seen. A lateral radiograph would be helpful to better assess the lower zones, which are partially obscured by the breast shadows.

The radiographic appearance is compatible with the history of atypical pneumonia. However, the upper lobe-predominant distribution of opacities would raise the question of other acute and chronic diseases, among them tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, and silicosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Air trapping and resulting hyperinflation are features of emphysema, typically seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency. Both conditions manifest with a chronic cough and exertional dyspnea; however, they also typically manifest with expectoration, cyanosis, and weight loss. This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for COPD and emphysema, but she is still quite young to develop it. Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency would also often lead to liver disease (e.g., hepatitis, hepatomegaly, cirrhosis). In either case, chest x-ray of emphysema would show hyperlucency, low and flattened diaphragm, and wide intercostal spaces, which are all absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

Large lung volumes (green outline and arrows) are accompanied by intercostal space widening (examples indicated by red arrows) and diaphragmatic flattening, indicating hyperinflation.

F) INCORRECT:

Bronchial hyperresponsiveness is one of the processes which causes allergic asthma. Asthma can manifest with a dry cough and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. Also, the patient's history of allergies increases her risk of developing allergic asthma. However, allergic asthma does not manifest with joint pain, hypercalcemia, or enlarged hilar lymph nodes.
Image Description:

Endobronchial obstruction and the characteristic clinical presentation of asthma (i.e., dyspnea, end-expiratory wheezing, and persistent cough) are caused by bronchospasm, mucosal edema, and increased mucus production (bronchial hypersecretion).
questions.hint: This patient's 6-month history of cough, exertional shortness of breath, and bilateral ankle pain in combination with the findings of hypercalcemia and hilar lymphadenopathy suggest a diagnosis of sarcoidosis, which is most common in young, black women.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for a preoperative evaluation. She is scheduled to undergo resection of a lipoma on her upper back in 2 weeks. She feels well. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus that is well-controlled with metformin. Her mother died of interstitial lung disease at the age of 50 years. The patient is sexually active with her husband, and they use condoms consistently. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. She drinks one to two glasses of wine per day. She does not use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination, including ophthalmologic evaluation, shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including serum creatinine and calcium concentrations, are within normal limits. An ECG shows no abnormalities. A tuberculin skin test is negative. A chest x-ray shows bilateral lobulated hilar masses; a radiograph is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's pulmonary findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ANCA testing is important in the diagnostic workup for autoimmune vasculitides, including granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which can also cause bilateral lesions on chest x-ray. However, the lesions associated with GPA are typically cavitating nodules (not bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy). Also, patients usually present with symptoms including chronic sinusitis, cough, and hematuria (from renal involvement).

B) INCORRECT:

A biopsy of affected tissue is the gold standard for diagnosing sarcoidosis. Histopathologic examination typically shows noncaseating granulomas with giant cells. However, patients who are asymptomatic with findings of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy do not require biopsy, as the risks outweigh the benefits of establishing a definitive diagnosis, and less invasive methods of investigation (e.g., physical examination, laboratory studies, spirometry) are sufficient.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral methotrexate therapy is a second-line treatment for patients with symptomatic pulmonary sarcoidosis (e.g., dyspnea, cough, chest pain) and patients with extrapulmonary manifestations (e.g., ocular or cutaneous symptoms) of sarcoidosis. However, this patient only has isolated, asymptomatic pulmonary sarcoidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoid therapy is the first-line treatment for patients with symptomatic pulmonary sarcoidosis (e.g., dyspnea, cough, chest pain) or extrapulmonary manifestations of sarcoidosis (e.g., ocular or cutaneous symptoms). Because this patient only has isolated, asymptomatic pulmonary sarcoidosis, oral glucocorticoid therapy is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

The interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) tests for latent tuberculosis (TB) infection, which is important to rule out in patients undergoing evaluation for sarcoidosis. In general, IGRA has greater specificity than tuberculin skin test (TST). However, patients with sarcoidosis have diminished skin reactivity, making the TST very specific (though less sensitive). Because this patient lacks pulmonary symptoms and a history indicating TB, a negative TST is sufficient to exclude this diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

In most patients with isolated pulmonary sarcoidosis, no specific treatment is required, as the disease is often asymptomatic and nonprogressive with a high rate of spontaneous remission. This patient has already received a thorough initial evaluation, including a tuberculin skin test, chest x-ray, ECG, and ophthalmologic examination. Pulmonary function testing would also be appropriate for this patient. There is a lack of data on the optimal frequency and type of monitoring for pulmonary sarcoidosis, but typical approaches include regular examinations every 3–6 months to assess symptoms, pulmonary function, and chest x-ray.

Oral glucocorticoids are the first-line treatment for patients with symptomatic pulmonary sarcoidosis (e.g., dyspnea, cough, chest pain) or extrapulmonary manifestations of sarcoidosis (e.g., ocular or cutaneous symptoms).
questions.hint: The lobulated enlargement of the pulmonary hila is consistent with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. This is a classic finding in patients with sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of fatigue, increasing shortness of breath on exertion, and a dry cough. She also has chronic constipation with bowel movements once every two to three days. She has not had fevers, night sweats, or weight loss. She has a history of hypertension and arthritis of both ankle joints. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and daily multivitamins. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Her serum sodium is 138 mEq/L, potassium is 3.9 mEq/L, and calcium is 11.5 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and normal lung parenchyma. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In sarcoidosis, macrophages within noncaseating granulomas express elevated levels of 1α-hydroxylase that converts 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 to the metabolically active 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3. The expression of 1α-hydroxylase increases secondary to the secretion of interferon γ by activated T lymphocytes in the course of the immune response. The elevated levels of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 increase intestinal calcium absorption resulting in hypercalcemia. At the same time, parathyroid hormone secretion from the parathyroid glands is inhibited by the high calcium levels but the reduced bone resorption and increased renal calcium excretion do not level out the action of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 on the intestines. Unlike renal 1α-hydroxylase, this process does not respond to negative feedback mediated by elevated 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 levels. Elevated levels of 1α-hydroxylase can also be found in other granulomatous conditions, such as Hodgkin lymphoma or tuberculosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic production of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) is a common cause of hypercalcemia in a wide variety of malignancies, including squamous cell lung cancer (SCLC). This patient's cough, dyspnea, and fatigue may be signs of SCLC but the absence of other constitutional symptoms (hemoptysis, weight loss, night sweats) make this condition less likely. In addition, chest x-ray in SCLC is likely to show solitary nodules rather than bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and normal lung parenchyma. Although the production of PTHrP may be increased in some patients with sarcoidosis, PTHrP production is not the primary cause of hypercalcemia in these patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Parathyroid adenomas are the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism, which leads to elevated levels of parathyroid hormone in the blood, resulting in increased calcium and phosphate release from bone, calcium reabsorption from the renal distal tubule, and renal production of calcitriol. Patients may present with hypercalcemia and constipation. However, the dry cough, dyspnea, fatigue, and chest x-ray results in this patient suggest another cause of hypercalcemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Use of thiazides (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) can induce hypercalcemia via action on the distal convoluted tubule. Inhibition of Na+/Cl- channel leads to upregulation of the basolateral Na+/Ca2+ antiporter, which transports Ca2+ into the interstitium in exchange for Na+ ions, resulting in an increase of Ca2+ resorption from the urine. However, hypercalcemia is typically mild due to intact parathyroid hormone feedback suppression and the effects of thiazides would not explain this patient's bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, exertional dyspnea, or anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic kidney disease (CKD) can cause hypertension, anemia, and fatigue, as well as certain electrolyte abnormalities. In cases of fluid overload, CKD can also manifest with shortness of breath and cough. However, unlike in this patient, CKD typically results in hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia (not hypercalcemia). Calcium levels in patients with CKD are decreased due to impaired vitamin D production. Also, excess phosphate binds to circulating calcium, which further decreases calcium levels. Finally, CKD would not explain this patient's other findings (hilar lymphadenopathy, bilateral arthritis).

F) INCORRECT:

Chronic vitamin A toxicity may result from excessive vitamin supplementation, which could be the case in this patient who takes daily multivitamins. Symptoms of chronic hypervitaminosis A include fatigue and arthralgias. Hypervitaminosis A might also result in hypercalcemia as this condition interferes with the ability of vitamin D to ensure calcium homeostasis. However, this patient's respiratory symptoms and findings on chest x-ray suggest a different etiology for increased calcium levels.
questions.hint: Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, hypercalcemia, progressive pulmonary symptoms, and a history of arthritis with bilateral ankle joint involvement raise concern for sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, constipation, and a nonproductive cough. Six months ago, she returned from a trip to Nigeria from where she emigrated as a child. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum calcium concentration is 11.7 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with coarse, nodular opacities in both lower lobes. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of the affected area of the lungs is shown. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the formation of this patient's histopathological findings?

choices.text: MHC I binding to CD8+ T cells
TGF-β secretion by regulatory T cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MHC I is a transmembrane protein expressed by all nucleated cells and platelets. MHC I binds endogenously synthesized antigens (e.g., viral and cytosolic proteins) to present to CD8+ T cells. This enables the rapid detection and destruction of cells infected by intracellular pathogens (e.g., viruses) and cells that produce atypical proteins (neoplastic or malignant cells) via cytotoxic T cells. However, this patient presents with findings of sarcoidosis, not a viral infection. MHC I is not involved in the pathogenesis of sarcoidosis.
Image Description:

MHC class I antigen presentation: Intracellular proteins are degraded to small peptide fragments by the proteasome and released into the cytosol. The cytosolic peptides enter the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) via the transporter associated with antigen processing (TAP) to form a complex with MHC class I molecule. The newly formed MHC class I antigen complex undergoes post-translational modification within the Golgi apparatus and enters the cell surface for presentation to cytotoxic CD8 T-cells.

MHC class II antigen presentation: Extracellular proteins are ingested by the antigen-presenting cell and held within the endosome. The protein is degraded into small peptides by the lysosome, which then forms a complex with the MHC class II protein. The new MHC class II antigen complex is transported to the cell surface for presentation with CD4 T-cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Antigen binding to IgM is typically seen in type II hypersensitivity reactions, in which IgM and IgG antibodies bind to antigens mistakenly detected as foreign in particular tissue types, activating complement and resulting in tissue destruction. Type II hypersensitivity reactions play a role in many autoimmune diseases (e.g., Goodpasture syndrome), some of which can manifest with fatigue and pulmonary symptoms such as those seen here. However, they do not typically manifest with the bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, hypercalcemia, and noncaseating granulomas on biopsy as seen here. IgM is not involved in the pathogenesis of sarcoidosis.

C) INCORRECT:

TGF-β secretion by regulatory T cells prevents autoimmunity by inhibiting B-lymphocytes and macrophages and activating regulatory T cells and Th17 cells. IL-10 from regulatory T cells downregulates the expression of MHC class II molecules, inhibits the secretion of Th1 cytokines, and suppresses activated macrophages and dendritic cells. These mechanisms prevent autoimmune disease by maintaining tolerance to self-antigens. However, this patient presents with findings of sarcoidosis, and TGF-β secretion is not involved in the pathogenesis of sarcoidosis.

D) CORRECT:

TNF-α secretion by macrophages is part of the pathogenesis of sarcoidosis and supports granuloma formation, which are shown in the photomicrograph of this patient's biopsy specimen. In sarcoidosis, dysfunctional CD4+ T cells are activated by an unknown factor and secrete Th1 cytokines such as IFN-γ, which promote macrophage activation and aggregation of macrophages into giant cells to form a granuloma. Activated macrophages, in turn, secrete TNF-α, which promotes maintenance of the granuloma. Because TNF-α is instrumental for granulomas, it is important to test for latent tuberculosis (TB; another granulomatous disease) before prescribing TNF-α inhibitors, which can cause disassembly of TB-sequestering granulomas, resulting in systemic TB.

E) INCORRECT:

IL-5 secretion by Th2 cells occurs in a type I hypersensitivity reaction, an overreaction of the immune system that results in immediate anaphylactic or atopic symptoms (pruritus, edema, rash, rhinitis, and bronchospasm). This reaction occurs when preformed IgE antibodies, which coat mast cells and basophils, come in contact with a free antigen and become crosslinked with each other. This results in cellular degranulation and release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators such as IL-5 (secreted by Th2 cells). IL-5 promotes eosinophils and class switching to IgA. This patient, however, presents with findings of sarcoidosis, not type I hypersensitivity. IL-5 secretion is not involved in the pathogenesis of sarcoidosis.
Image Description:

IgE is typically bound to Fc receptors (FcR) on the surface of immune cells, such as mast cells and basophils. Crosslinking of an allergen with the IgE signals the immune cells to degranulate, releasing inflammatory mediators (e.g., histamine) that instantly trigger a hypersensitivity reaction.

This is the pathophysiology of type I hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis, food allergies, drug reactions), which can be severe enough to result in anaphylactic shock.
questions.hint: The presence of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, hypercalcemia, and respiratory symptoms is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis, a disease characterized by the formation of noncaseating granulomas, with a higher prevalence in African Americans.

questions.text: A 29-year-old African-American woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fever, progressive shortness of breath, and a dry cough. During this time, she has also had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. Two months ago, she was in Kenya for several weeks to visit her family. Physical examination shows fine crackles and wheezing over both lung fields. Her serum calcium concentration is 11.8 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows reticular opacities in both lungs and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Necrotizing inflammation is seen in a variety of conditions, including tuberculosis. Patients with tuberculosis classically present with weight loss, fever, cough, and hilar lymphadenopathy. Severe pulmonary tuberculosis can also result in hypercalcemia. Furthermore, this patient's trip to Kenya, a high-risk country for tuberculosis, should raise concern for this condition. However, active tuberculosis generally manifests with a productive cough and would likely be accompanied by hemoptysis, night sweats, and cavitary lesions in the upper lung lobes, none of which is seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of pulmonary tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

An abundance of leukocytes is visible in the center of the image. The immune cells appear to form circular patterns enclosing extracellular matrix. Necrotic pulmonary tissue is visible on the right border.

These findings are consistent with pulmonary tuberculosis.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) CORRECT:

Sarcoidosis is a multisystem disorder characterized by chronic inflammation and noncaseating granuloma formation due to immune system dysregulation. T-cell dysfunction and increased B-cell activity lead to local immune hyperactivity, inflammation, and subsequent formation of noncaseating granulomas. The lungs and the lymphatic system are most commonly affected, although sarcoidosis is a systemic disorder that may affect any organ.

Other granulomatous diseases include tuberculosis, pneumoconiosis, Crohn disease, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung resection specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

Multiple noncaseating granulomas are visible individually (example indicated by red overlay) or forming a mass (green overlay), surrounded by normal pulmonary tissue.

Noncaseating granulomas are a typical finding in pulmonary sarcoidosis.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchial hyperresponsiveness is characteristic of asthma, which can manifest with a dry cough, shortness of breath, and wheezing. However, patients with asthma classically have episodic exacerbations (asthma attacks) rather than progressively worsening symptoms. Moreover, asthma would not explain the weight loss, hypercalcemia, and x-ray findings in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Certain viral infections manifest as atypical pneumonia. Patients with atypical pneumonia can have symptoms similar to those seen in this patient (e.g., fever, nonproductive cough, dyspnea, auscultatory crackles). Moreover, a chest x-ray can show reticular opacities as seen here. However, atypical pneumonia would not explain the weight loss, hypercalcemia, and hilar lymphadenopathy in this patient.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a female patient with a history of atypical pneumonia

Opacities are distributed bilaterally, predominantly in the upper lobes. Some of the opacities appear linear (examples indicated by red overlay), while others appear nodular (examples indicated by white arrowheads). Areas of confluent opacification (example indicated by green overlay) are also seen. A lateral radiograph would be helpful to better assess the lower zones, which are partially obscured by the breast shadows.

The radiographic appearance is compatible with the history of atypical pneumonia. However, the upper lobe-predominant distribution of opacities would raise the question of other acute and chronic diseases, among them tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, and silicosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Monoclonal plasma cell production is characteristic of multiple myeloma, which can also manifest with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss) and hypercalcemia. However, multiple myeloma would not explain the pulmonary symptoms and the x-ray findings in this patient. Moreover, multiple myeloma often presents with back pain, which is not seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with lung cancer (e.g., squamous cell carcinoma of the lung) can also present with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss), a nonproductive cough, and hypercalcemia (i.e., humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy). However, a chest x-ray would likely show solitary nodules rather than the bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and reticular opacities seen here. Moreover, lung cancer is rare in young patients (especially those without a history of smoking).
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with bronchogenic carcinoma

A solitary nodule (red overlay) with an irregular margin is visible in the periphery of the upper left lung. An additional soft-tissue opacity peripheral to the nodule along the ribs may represent adjacent pleural thickening (green overlay).

The differential diagnosis for a solitary pulmonary nodule includes neoplastic (malignant and benign), inflammatory, and congenital conditions.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a 4-month history of shortness of breath and a dry cough. In combination with hypercalcemia and hilar lymphadenopathy, these features are suggestive of a diagnosis of sarcoidosis, which is most common in young African American women.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, and pain in her knees and ankles. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). Physical examination shows mild hepatomegaly and tender, red nodules on her shins. There are purple, indurated lesions on her nose, nasolabial fold, and cheeks. A biopsy of the liver shows scattered aggregations of multinucleated giant cells with cytoplasmic inclusions and eosinophilic, needle-shaped structures arranged in a star-like pattern. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms (fatigue, dyspnea, arthralgia, hepatomegaly, erythema nodosum, and lupus pernio) are classically found in patients with sarcoidosis. Other features can include a dry cough, peripheral lymphadenopathy, and uveitis. A biopsy of a non-caseating granuloma typically shows asteroid bodies and/or Schaumann bodies.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can manifest with arthralgia, fatigue, dyspnea, hepatomegaly, erythema nodosum, and facial rash, which are seen in this patient. However, in SLE, the classic skin lesion is a malar rash (“butterfly rash”), with sparing of the nasolabial folds and photosensitivity. Moreover, a biopsy would likely show a lupus band (immunoglobulin and complement component deposits) along the dermo-epidermal junction; granulomas and inclusion bodies would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypereosinophilic syndrome can manifest with fatigue, dyspnea, arthralgia, and hepatomegaly, as well as erythema nodosum in some cases. However, skin lesions more commonly seen in hypereosinophilic syndrome include itchy rash with papules and plaques, urticarial wheals, and angioedema, none of which is seen in this patient. Furthermore, a liver biopsy of a patient with hypereosinophilic syndrome would show eosinophilic infiltrates in the portal system and, in some cases, biliary system damage, not granulomas or inclusion bodies.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemochromatosis can also manifest with fatigue, arthralgia, and hepatomegaly, which are seen in this patient. However, in a patient with hemochromatosis signs of diabetes (polyuria, polydipsia) and skin bronzing would be expected, rather than cutaneous nodules. Moreover, biopsy specimens of a liver affected by hemochromatosis would show hemosiderin deposits, not granulomas or inclusion bodies.

E) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma is also characterized by granuloma formation and manifests with fatigue, dyspnea (due to a mediastinal mass), arthralgia, and hepatomegaly, which are seen in this patient. However, in a patient with Hodgkin lymphoma, painless lymphadenopathy (cervical > axillary > inguinal) would be expected, rather than cutaneous nodules. Moreover, biopsy of a Hodgkin lymphoma would likely show Reed-Sternberg cells, not inclusion bodies.

F) INCORRECT:

Serum sickness can be caused by hepatitis B infection and manifests with fatigue, arthralgia, and hepatomegaly. However, a patient with serum sickness would classically present with high-grade fever and urticarial rash, not erythema nodosum. Moreover, serum sickness is a transient illness (symptoms appear 1–2 weeks following exposure and resolve within a few weeks), while this patient's symptoms have worsened over an extended period (3 months). Finally, a biopsy would show councilman bodies, Kupffer cell proliferation, and/or bridging necrosis, not granulomas or inclusion bodies.
questions.hint: This patient's liver biopsy specimen shows asteroid bodies (needle-shaped structures arranged in a star-like pattern), which are typical of a foreign body-type, non-caseating, granulomatous inflammation.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of fatigue, intermittent fever, a 4.0-kg (9-lb) weight loss, and a progressive, nonproductive cough. She does not smoke. Physical examination shows mild wheezing over bilateral lung fields and enlarged supraclavicular and cervical lymph nodes. A CT scan of the chest is shown. A biopsy specimen of a cervical lymph node shows organized epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells without focal necrosis. The initial treatment of this patient's condition should include which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cisplatin is a chemotherapeutic agent commonly used in the treatment of lung cancers, which can manifest with a nonproductive cough, weight loss, and lymphadenopathy. However, lung cancers usually appear as solitary masses on CT scans, and biopsy findings would show dysplastic cancer cells. In addition, lung cancers are most commonly associated with a history of smoking, which is not present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic commonly used to treat community-acquired pneumonia, which can manifest with constitutional symptoms and cough. However, symptoms would be short-lived and would not continue for 6 months. CT scan would show areas of consolidation, while biopsy would show features of acute inflammation and bacteria. Azithromycin is also used in the treatment of Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infections, which can manifest with the symptoms seen in this patient and also show noncaseating granulomatous inflammation. However, MAC infection would be unusual in a nonimmunosuppressed patient and would not cause bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Isoniazid is an antibiotic that is used in the treatment of tuberculosis (TB). While TB can manifest with cough, lymphadenopathy, and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, fatigue), the cough in TB is usually productive. Furthermore, cavitary lung lesions are more common than significant hilar lymphadenopathy. Most importantly, biopsy findings would show granulomas with central necrosis (i.e., caseating granulomas) rather than epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells without focal necrosis (i.e., non-caseating granulomas).

D) INCORRECT:

Bleomycin is a chemotherapeutic agent that is part of the regimen used to manage Hodgkin lymphoma. While Hodgkin lymphoma can manifest with lymphadenopathy, weight loss, and B symptoms (fever, night sweats, and weight loss), biopsy findings would show Reed-Sternberg cells rather than epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyclophosphamide is the drug of choice in the management of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which can manifest with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, fatigue) and pulmonary involvement. However, biopsy findings in GPA would show necrotizing granulomatous inflammation rather than epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells without focal necrosis.

Cyclophosphamide is sometimes also used for the treatment of sarcoidosis. However, this drug is typically reserved for patients with severe symptomatic disease who do not respond to first-line treatment or for extrapulmonary forms of sarcoidosis such as neurosarcoidosis and would thus not be part of the initial medication regimen in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical features (dry cough, weight loss, fatigue, lymphadenopathy), CT scan findings (pronounced bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy), and biopsy findings (epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells without necrosis, which describes noncaseating granulomas) are diagnostic for sarcoidosis. The first-line treatment in patients with symptomatic pulmonary sarcoidosis consists of glucocorticoids, e.g., prednisone. After an intensive daily steroid regimen for a period of 6 months, steroids are tapered to a low dose for long-term use. Glucocorticoids provide symptomatic relief and improve pulmonary function. Other agents (e.g., methotrexate) can be used in patients with contraindications to steroids or severe adverse effects, or in those who do not respond to glucocorticoids.
questions.hint: Serum studies of this patient would most likely show elevated angiotensin-converting enzyme concentrations.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a dry cough. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows mild conjunctival hyperemia. Chest auscultation shows fine crackles in both lung fields. Laboratory studies show a total calcium concentration of 10.8 mg/dL. The results of spirometry are shown (dashed loop shows normal for comparison). Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show an increase in which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of monoclonal IgG are seen in multiple myeloma, which can cause hypercalcemia. However, myeloma affects the bone marrow and manifests with bone pain, pathological fractures, or features of anemia (e.g., pallor, fatigue). Lung involvement in myeloma is extremely rare. This patient most likely has sarcoidosis, which is associated with elevated IgG levels in about 50% of cases, but these are not monoclonal antibodies.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) cause hypercalcemia. A common cause of PTHrP secretion is squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung, which is an important differential diagnosis in this patient given her cough. However, SCC of the lung typically occurs among smokers and it does not explain the bilateral crackles, conjunctival hyperemia, or spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease. This patient most likely has sarcoidosis, in which hypercalcemia is caused by increased 1-alpha hydroxylase activity rather than PTHrP secretion.

C) INCORRECT:

Mast cell tryptase is typically elevated in asthma, which can manifest with a dry cough. Individuals with allergic bronchial asthma often also have allergic conjunctivitis, which causes conjunctival hyperemia. However, asthma typically causes wheezes rather than fine crackles, and the flow-volume loop would show a shift to the left with decreased expiratory airflow (obstructive lung disease). Moreover, asthma does not explain the hypercalcemia in this patient.
Image Description:

Patients with an obstructive lung disease typically have a concave flow-volume loop (middle) compared to healthy patients (left).
Emphysema typically causes a “scooped out” curve (right) due to the collapse of small airways during expiration.

D) INCORRECT:

Neutrophil elastase activity is typically elevated in smokers and individuals with alpha-1 antitrypsin (ATT) deficiency. Both ATT deficiency and smoking are risk factors for emphysema, which can cause a dry cough. However, the flow-volume loop of patients with emphysema would show a shift to the left with decreased expiratory airflow (obstructive lung disease) and scalloping of the expiratory flow curve. Moreover, emphysema does not explain the hypercalcemia seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Patients with an obstructive lung disease typically have a concave flow-volume loop (middle) compared to healthy patients (left).
Emphysema typically causes a “scooped out” curve (right) due to the collapse of small airways during expiration.

E) CORRECT:

Sarcoidosis is a condition that causes noncaseating granulomatous inflammation. The epithelioid cells of pulmonary granulomas produce angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) and increased ACE activity is a possible finding in patients with sarcoidosis. Hypercalcemia in sarcoidosis is the result of increased 1-alpha hydroxylase activity in the activated pulmonary macrophages. Patients with sarcoidosis can also develop polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia. Another finding associated with sarcoidosis is an increased CD4+:CD8+ cell ratio in bronchoalveolar lavage. This finding can be used to differentiate sarcoidosis from hypersensitivity pneumonitis, which is associated with a low CD4+:CD8+ cell ratio.

F) INCORRECT:

Cold agglutinin titers are elevated following Mycoplasma pneumonia, which manifests with a dry subacute cough, fine crackles, and features of restrictive lung disease on spirometry. Conjunctivitis is also a common extrapulmonary manifestation of Mycoplasma pneumonia. However, Mycoplasma pneumonia does not explain the hypercalcemia in this patient.
questions.hint: The flow-volume loop shows a shift to the right and a decrease in total lung volume with a relative sparing of airflow during expiration. These features are consistent with restrictive lung disease (RLD). The constellation of a dry cough, hypercalcemia, and spirometric findings of RLD is consistent with sarcoidosis. Patients with sarcoidosis may develop conjunctival hyperemia due to conjunctivitis, uveitis, or scleritis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of left-sided facial droop for the last 24 hours. She says that she cannot fully close her left eye, which has become dry and itchy. For the past 4 weeks, the patient has had fatigue and malaise. She has also had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss during this time period despite having normal appetite. For 3 weeks, she has experienced painful, “reddish bumps” on her shins. She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her medications are lisinopril and metformin. She works as a teacher in Idaho and has never traveled outside the US. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/65 mm Hg. Examination discloses left peripheral facial nerve palsy and cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the patient's skin lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her facial palsy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sjogren syndrome can manifest with extraglandular symptoms, such as facial nerve palsy and EN. However, Sjogren syndrome is characterized by inflammation of the salivary and lacrimal glands, resulting in bilateral xerophthalmia and xerostomia. This patient's unilateral facial nerve palsy is most likely due to another condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Lyme disease can manifest with malaise, fatigue, and a skin rash in stage I and facial nerve palsy in stage II. However, erythema migrans, not erythema nodosum, is the rash most commonly associated with Lyme disease and appears as a slowly enlarging red lesion with a central clearing. Moreover, Lyme disease is not endemic in Idaho, and this patient's weight loss points to another cause for her facial nerve palsy.
Image Description:

A large, primary lesion with circular erythema and central clearing on the posterior side of the right upper arm is visible.

This clinical picture is typical of erythema migrans (stage-I Lyme disease).

Illustration: Bull's eye sign

C) INCORRECT:

Although type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) can cause cranial mononeuropathy, DM typically affects cranial nerve III (CN III), CN IV, and CN VI, rather than the facial nerve. Necrobiosis lipoidica, not EN, is the cutaneous finding most commonly associated with DM. Moreover, necrobiosis lipoidica manifests as a painless rash located in the dermis, not as painful nodules in the subcutaneous fat. The combination of lymphadenopathy, malaise, weight loss, and EN in this patient suggests a different underlying cause for her facial nerve palsy.
Image Description:

Several well-demarcated, irregularly shaped, yellow-erythematous plaques are visible on both lower legs.

This appearance is characteristic of necrobiosis lipoidica.

D) INCORRECT:

Reactivated and extrapulmonary tuberculosis (TB) can manifest with a wide range of symptoms, including cranial nerve palsy (e.g., facial nerve palsy, abducens nerve palsy), malaise, lymphadenopathy, weight loss, and EN. Cranial nerve palsy in TB occurs as a symptom of tuberculous meningitis, which manifests with stiff neck, fever, vomiting, and altered mental status. Moreover, cranial nerve deficits in TB most commonly involve the abducens nerve. Finally, this patient has no risk factors for tuberculosis (e.g., crowded living conditions, history of travel to a TB-endemic country). Although tuberculosis should certainly be ruled out in this patient, another etiology is more likely responsible for her facial nerve palsy.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with signs and symptoms of multisystem disease, including fatigue, malaise, erythema nodosum, weight loss, and lymphadenopathy. These findings, combined with her age and female sex, are consistent with sarcoidosis, an inflammatory condition that primarily affects the lungs but can manifest in any organ, including the nervous system. Patients with neurosarcoidosis most commonly present with facial nerve palsy; some may have meningitis, peripheral neuropathy, myopathy, and neuroendocrine dysfunction, such as hypopituitarism or central diabetes insipidus.

Chest x-ray is the most appropriate initial test (even in patients without respiratory symptoms) and typically shows hilar lymphadenopathy with or without bilateral reticular opacities; lymph node biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis. Histopathology is used to rule out differential diagnoses, such as tuberculosis or lymphoma.
questions.hint: The painful violaceous nodules seen on this patient's shins are consistent with erythema nodosum (EN), an inflammation of the subcutaneous fat that is typically idiopathic but may be associated with certain infections or autoimmune diseases. This patient's EN is accompanied by generalized symptoms (fatigue, weight loss) and peripheral facial nerve palsy, suggesting a systemic condition.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a rash that developed on her face 3 months ago. The rash is not painful or pruritic. She tried taking an over-the-counter antiallergy medication but it provided no relief. She also has a 1-year history of dry, nonproductive cough and mild exertional dyspnea. The patient emigrated from Azerbaijan 35 years ago. She drinks one glass of wine daily and smokes one pack of cigarettes every 2–3 days. She works as a dental technician. Her BMI is 24 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. A photograph of the patient's lesion is shown. There is diffuse wheezing on pulmonary auscultation. The liver edge is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. The spleen tip is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. The results of an antinuclear antibody test are within the normal range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lupus vulgaris is a cutaneous manifestation of tuberculosis (TB) and affected patients typically present with facial plaques or nodules. Moreover, TB is endemic in Azerbaijan and pulmonary involvement is common; therefore, TB should be considered a possible diagnosis in this patient. Lupus vulgaris manifests with painful skin lesions, however, that typically ulcerate, whereas this patient's lesions are nonulcerating and painless. Finally, this woman lacks additional features of TB, including fever and weight loss.
Image Description:

Localization: skin covering the right mandible
Lesion: flat to slightly raised, irregularly demarcated, squamous skin lesion, which may ulcerate in the future

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can manifest with facial erythema with nasolabial sparing. Moreover, lung involvement can also occur in SLE. While SLE typically affects women, disease onset is most commonly between 15 and 44 years of age. Furthermore, the absence of antinuclear antibodies and other common features of SLE, such as constitutional symptoms and arthralgia, suggests a different condition.
Image Description:

An erythematous macular rash with adherent keratotic scaling is visible over the nasal bridge, cheek (malar eminence), brow, and chin. The rash has spared the nasolabial fold. Mild cheilitis is also visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of the malar rash typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus. Because this rash typically affects both malar eminences symmetrically, resembling butterfly wings, it is also referred to as a "butterfly rash."

C) CORRECT:

Lupus pernio, a pathognomonic manifestation of extrapulmonary sarcoidosis, typically manifests with nonpruritic, painless violaceous skin plaques and/or nodules on the nose and cheeks, as seen here. Symptoms of interstitial lung fibrosis (dry, nonproductive cough, exertional dyspnea), hepatosplenomegaly, and lupus pernio suggest chronic sarcoidosis, which most frequently affects women between 25–35 and 50–65 years of age. Sarcoidosis is an immune-mediated inflammatory condition that primarily affects the lungs but can manifest in any organ (e.g., lymph nodes, eyes, skin, liver, spleen, nervous system).

D) INCORRECT:

Rosacea commonly occurs in middle-aged women and can manifest with central facial erythema. Although alcohol may trigger rosacea, this patient's rash is persistent, with no described triggers. Moreover, this patient does not have telangiectasia, papules, or pustules, which are commonly seen in rosacea. Finally, the presence of hepatosplenomegaly and pulmonary symptoms would not be expected in rosacea.
Image Description:

There is erythema, telangiectasia, papules, and pustules localized to the nose and cheeks.

These are characteristic features of rosacea.

E) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid syndrome manifests with cutaneous flushing of the face, dyspnea, and wheezing. However, the flushing in carcinoid syndrome is typically triggered by alcohol consumption, food intake, or stress and lasts up to 30 minutes, whereas this patient's rash is persistent, with no described triggers. Furthermore, carcinoid syndrome commonly manifests with diarrhea and weight loss, neither of which this patient has.
questions.hint: A biopsy of the lesion will most likely show epithelioid, noncaseating granulomas.

The initial treatment of this patient's condition should include which of the following drugs?

A) INCORRECT:

Isoniazid is an antibiotic that is used in the treatment of tuberculosis (TB). While TB can manifest with cough, lymphadenopathy, and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, fatigue), the cough in TB is usually productive. Furthermore, cavitary lung lesions are more common than significant hilar lymphadenopathy. Most importantly, biopsy findings would show granulomas with central necrosis (i.e., caseating granulomas) rather than epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells without focal necrosis (i.e., non-caseating granulomas).

B) INCORRECT:

Lamivudine is a component of HAART for HIV, which can manifest with weight loss, cough, and lymphadenopathy. However, biopsy findings in HIV-associated lymphadenopathy would show predominantly reactive hyperplasia with no evidence of histiocytes or granulomatous inflammation. Furthermore, this patient has no risk factors for HIV infection (e.g., a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, commercial sex work, or intravenous drug abuse).

C) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical features (dry cough, weight loss, fatigue, lymphadenopathy), CT scan findings (pronounced bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy), and biopsy findings (epitheloid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells without necrosis, which describes noncaseating granulomas) are diagnostic for sarcoidosis. The first-line treatment in patients with symptomatic pulmonary sarcoidosis consists of glucocorticoids, e.g., prednisone. After an intensive daily steroid regimen for a period of 6 months, steroids are then tapered to a low dose for long-term use. Glucocorticoids provide symptomatic relief and improve pulmonary function. Other agents, e.g., methotrexate, can be used in patients with contraindications to steroids or severe adverse effects, or in those who do not respond to glucocorticoids.

D) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic commonly used to treat community-acquired pneumonia, which can manifest with constitutional symptoms and cough. However, symptoms would be short-lived and would not continue for 6 months. CT scan would show areas of consolidation, while biopsy would show features of acute inflammation and bacteria. Azithromycin is also used in the treatment of Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infections, which can manifest with the symptoms seen in this patient and also show noncaseating granulomatous inflammation. However, MAC infection would be unusual in a nonimmunosuppressed patient and would not cause bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Bleomycin is a chemotherapeutic agent that is part of the regimen used to manage Hodgkin lymphoma. While Hodgkin lymphoma can manifest with lymphadenopathy, weight loss, and B symptoms (fever, night sweats, and weight loss), biopsy findings would show Reed-Sternberg cells rather than epitheloid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Cyclophosphamide is the drug of choice in the management of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which can manifest with constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, fatigue) and pulmonary involvement. However, biopsy findings in GPA would show necrotizing granulomatous inflammation rather than epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells without focal necrosis.

Cyclophosphamide is sometimes also used for the treatment of sarcoidosis. However, this drug is typically reserved for patients with severe symptomatic disease who do not respond to first-line treatment or for extrapulmonary forms of sarcoidosis such as neurosarcoidosis and would thus not be part of the initial medication regimen in this patient.
questions.hint: Serum studies of this patient would most likely show elevated angiotensin-converting enzyme concentrations.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male smoker with hypertension is hospitalized with a 6-month history of progressive dyspnea and lower-extremity edema. Two years earlier, he had intermittent complete heart block and had a permanent pacemaker inserted.
An echocardiogram reveals biventricular systolic dysfunction, with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40%, moderate mitral and tricuspid valve regurgitation, and mild concentric left ventricular hypertrophy.
An electrocardiogram reveals sinus rhythm with first-degree atrioventricular block and a left bundle-branch block pattern. Telemetric monitoring reveals frequent episodes of nonsustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, during which the patient appears to be hemodynamically stable. A 12-lead electrocardiogram is obtained during one of these episodes (figure).
Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography reveals normal coronary arteries. An endomyocardial biopsy documents normal myocardium.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac amyloidosis can manifest as a dilated cardiomyopathy with conduction abnormalities, but it is more likely to be detected with endomyocardial biopsy and is rarely associated with ventricular tachycardia.

B) CORRECT:

Cardiac sarcoidosis is often associated with conduction abnormalities, such as complete heart block, bundle-branch blocks, and ventricular arrhythmias. Those findings, in the setting of biventricular systolic dysfunction and electrocardiographic evidence of monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (as demonstrated in this patient’s electrocardiogram), suggest the diagnosis of a sarcoid cardiomyopathy. Because of the patchy involvement of the myocardium by noncaseating granulomas, endomyocardial biopsy is frequently normal; only 20% of biopsies show the characteristic noncaseating granulomas. Although many patients with cardiac sarcoidosis can be asymptomatic, the diagnosis should be considered in an otherwise healthy young patient with the above presentation or in a patient with known sarcoidosis who presents with any of the above findings.

Key learning point: The cardiomyopathy that would most likely be associated with normal coronary arteries, conduction abnormalities, and ventricular tachycardia is cardiac sarcoidosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Giant-cell myocarditis is a rare form of myocarditis that can be associated with ventricular tachycardia; however, patients with giant-cell myocarditis have a much more acute presentation, with severe and rapidly progressive heart failure. Unless glucocorticoid therapy is initiated early in the course of the disease, death quickly ensues.

D) INCORRECT:

A patient with normal coronary arteries does not have an ischemic cardiomyopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia is a type of cardiomyopathy that typically involves the right ventricle, although the left ventricle can be involved as well. It is characterized by fibrofatty replacement of the right ventricular myocardium, with right ventricular wall-motion abnormalities. Typically, there is a left bundle-branch pattern on electrocardiogram with an inferior axis.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman with a history of long-standing hypothyroidism reports several months of fatigue and intermittent palpitations. She denies any dyspnea, edema, chest pain, change in weight, or changes in her hair or skin. Her current medications are levothyroxine 75 μg daily and an oral contraceptive.
Her blood pressure is 123/64 mm Hg, her heart rate is 76 beats per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 98% while she is breathing ambient air. She has a BMI of 28.2. The remainder of her physical examination is unremarkable.
Her evaluation includes the following elements:

24-hour Holter monitoring, which identifies occasional premature ventricular complexes

Transthoracic echocardiogram, which reveals mild global hypokinesis and an ejection fraction of 46%

Chest radiograph, which shows clear lung fields, a normal cardiac silhouette, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy


Laboratory testing reveals normal findings on a chemistry panel, complete blood count, and thyroid function panel.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnostic evaluations should this patient undergo next?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endomyocardial biopsy has a low yield because of the patchy distribution of granulomas and is generally not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

After the diagnosis of sarcoidosis is confirmed by lymph node biopsy, cardiac MRI may be useful in evaluating patients for cardiac involvement.

C) CORRECT:

Cardiac sarcoidosis manifests with myriad signs and symptoms, ranging from none at all, to heart failure, to sudden cardiac death. Granulomas, which often involve the left ventricular free wall and the interventricular septum, may result in cardiomyopathy and conduction-system disorders such as atrioventricular block, bundle-branch block, or arrhythmias.

This patient’s demographic characteristics (young, female) are typical for a person with sarcoidosis. She also has bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, which raises suspicion for the disease. In addition, she has evidence of a right bundle-branch block and left ventricular systolic dysfunction. Although these features make the diagnosis of sarcoidosis likely, a confirmed histologic diagnosis is recommended. The most accessible source — in this case, the hilar lymph nodes — should be biopsied.

Key learning point: In a patient with evidence of systemic sarcoidosis, signs of cardiac involvement may include atrioventricular block and bundle-branch block, arrhythmias, segmental wall-motion abnormalities, heart failure, and sudden cardiac death.

D) INCORRECT:

Although sarcoid infiltration of the thyroid is a rare cause of goiter, it generally does not cause hypothyroidism. This patient has long-standing hypothyroidism and no goiter; hence, thyroid ultrasound is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

After the diagnosis of sarcoidosis is confirmed by lymph node biopsy, nuclear stress testing may be useful in evaluating patients for cardiac involvement.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man who has recently relocated to the area states that he has been followed for 5 years for “lung disease,” but he cannot provide specific details.
The patient’s vital signs are normal, and his oxygen saturation is 92% while he is breathing ambient air.
Spirometry results are as follows:


FEV1

1.92 liters per minute, 80% of predicted


FVC
2.80 liters, 89% of predicted


FEV1 /FVC ratio
69%


Physical examination reveals scattered wheezing and rare crackles throughout the mid-lung fields. In addition, the patient has painless skin lesions on his face and ears (figure) that he says were present when his disease was diagnosed.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and lymphocytic interstitial pneumonitis are not associated with dermatologic findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and lymphocytic interstitial pneumonitis are not associated with dermatologic findings.

C) INCORRECT:

The classic dermatologic finding in systemic lupus erythematous is a malar rash over the cheeks and bridge of the nose; it usually appears after sun exposure.

D) CORRECT:

Sarcoidosis is a systemic disorder of unknown cause. Respiratory disease is common, but the disorder can affect any organ system. Pulmonary function testing may reveal restriction, obstruction, or both. About 25% of patients with sarcoidosis develop one or more skin manifestations. Lupus pernio — a rare manifestation characterized by indurated, violaceous lesions that affect the ears, cheeks, eyelids, nose, hands, and fingers — is pathognomonic for sarcoidosis.

Key learning point: Lupus pernio — which is characterized by indurated, violaceous lesions that affect the ears, cheeks, eyelids, nose, hands, and fingers — is pathognomonic for sarcoidosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Coccidiomycosis is not associated with a pathognomonic dermatologic manifestation, but the skin is the most common site of dissemination, with lesions ranging from maculopapules to erythema nodosum or erythema multiforme.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents for evaluation of tender red nodules on the anterior surface of both legs that developed a few days ago (figure). She has had no fever, chills, weight loss, dyspnea, or anorexia. She has a history of hilar adenopathy that was documented by chest radiograph several years ago and was stable on a repeat chest radiograph.
Which one of the following treatments is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An antibiotic, such as levofloxacin, is not indicated in a patient who has no evidence of infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Other forms of immunosuppression, such as azathioprine or hydroxychloroquine, are indicated only when symptoms of sarcoidosis are uncontrolled by a systemic glucocorticoid or the disease advances despite treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Other forms of immunosuppression, such as azathioprine or hydroxychloroquine, are indicated only when symptoms of sarcoidosis are uncontrolled by a systemic glucocorticoid or the disease advances despite treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Sarcoidosis can manifest as hilar adenopathy (on a chest radiograph) and skin lesions, such as erythema nodosum. Erythema nodosum is the characteristic lesion of acute sarcoidosis; its tenderness can be mitigated by treatment with a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, such as ibuprofen.

Pulmonary sarcoidosis has four stages:
• Stage 1 (as in this case): bilateral hilar adenopathy
• Stage 2: bilateral hilar adenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
• Stage 3: parenchymal infiltrates without adenopathy
• Stage 4: signs of fibrosis

Patients with sarcoidosis, even those with pulmonary involvement, do not necessarily require systemic glucocorticoid therapy, such as prednisone. Treatment with a systemic glucocorticoid is deferred unless organ function is abnormal or the patient develops pulmonary parenchymal infiltrates (stage 2 and higher). A decision to use a glucocorticoid demands consideration of its substantial adverse effects.

Key learning point: The recommended initial treatment of erythema nodosum should include nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with sarcoidosis, even those with pulmonary involvement, do not necessarily require systemic glucocorticoid therapy, such as prednisone. Treatment with a systemic glucocorticoid is deferred unless organ function is abnormal or the patient develops pulmonary parenchymal infiltrates (stage 2 and higher).

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with fatigue and lightheadedness. He has a recent history of bilateral anterior uveitis and has had a hyperpigmented papular rash across his chest for the past few weeks. He denies fevers, cough, chest pain, or recent travel.
On examination, he is afebrile. He has a heart rate of 48 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 124/82 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air.
An electrocardiogram reveals third-degree heart block with a junctional escape at 48 beats per minute.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Sarcoidosis is characterized by the accumulation of epithelioid granulomas in various organs, including the lungs, skin, eyes, and heart. Cutaneous manifestations take many forms, including a papular rash. Anterior uveitis is the most common ocular manifestation, but sarcoidosis is one of the few diseases that can cause inflammation at any level of the uveal tract.

Cardiac sarcoidosis may be the initial manifestation of sarcoid disease and can cause conduction-system abnormalities, including complete heart block. Fatal arrythmias are also seen; patients may therefore require placement of an automated implantable cardioverter-defibrillator and even evaluation for cardiac transplantation. The mainstay of treatment for cardiac sarcoidosis is glucocorticoid therapy, which reduces inflammation and thereby prevents cardiac fibrosis.

Key learning point: The combination of uveitis and junctional bradycardia is most consistent with a diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis, hemochromatosis, and Lyme disease may also cause conduction-system disease but are not generally associated with uveitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis, hemochromatosis, and Lyme disease may also cause conduction-system disease but are not generally associated with uveitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Behçet disease typically causes oral and genital ulcers and may be associated with uveitis, but cardiac involvement is rare.

E) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis, hemochromatosis, and Lyme disease may also cause conduction-system disease but are not generally associated with uveitis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man from New Hampshire with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia is hospitalized with fever and joint pain. One week ago, he noted pain and swelling in both ankles. His fever developed the next day.
He has a current temperature of 39.2°C, a heart rate of 102 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 134/68 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 97% while he is breathing ambient air. Both ankles are swollen and tender to the touch. Joint examination reveals pain with active range of motion of the ankles, but passive range of motion is full and of minimal discomfort. Several tender cutaneous nodules with overlying erythema are noted over both anterior shins.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis and lymphoma can mimic Löfgren syndrome, as both can yield similar symptoms, although the triad of arthritis, erythema nodosum, and hilar adenopathy is rare.

B) INCORRECT:

Late-disseminated Lyme disease can manifest as a monoarthritis, but fever, adenopathy, and erythema nodosum are absent.

C) CORRECT:

Löfgren syndrome, an acute form of sarcoidosis, is defined by the triad of arthritis (or “periarthritis,” given that the inflammation often does not involve the joint itself but rather the periarticular tissues), erythema nodosum, and hilar adenopathy. Fever is common in acute presentations of sarcoidosis, such as Löfgren syndrome. Arthritis is often polyarticular and involves the ankles, particularly in men. Erythema nodosum is more common in women.

Löfgren syndrome is usually self-limited and carries a favorable prognosis. However, treatment with glucocorticoids or nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs is often needed for control of pain.

Key learning point: The triad of arthritis, erythema nodosum, and hilar adenopathy is characteristic of Löfgren syndrome, an acute form of sarcoidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis and lymphoma can mimic Löfgren syndrome, as both can yield similar symptoms, although the triad of arthritis, erythema nodosum, and hilar adenopathy is rare.

E) INCORRECT:

Coccidioidomycosis has a limited geographical distribution, and the hilar adenopathy is often unilateral and associated with pulmonary infiltrates.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man reports several months of fatigue, mild dyspnea, and dry cough. He has not had fevers, chest pain, palpitations, sputum production, edema, weight gain, or reflux, but he has noted painless, darkened patches on his nose and cheeks.
Physical examination confirms nontender, violaceous plaques on the patient’s nose and cheeks (figure).
Laboratory test results of electrolytes, kidney and liver function, and complete blood counts are normal. He has an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 47 mm/hr (reference range, 0–17) and a C-reactive protein level of 12.00 mg/liter (0.08–3.10).
A chest radiograph shows bilateral hilar adenopathy. A purified protein derivative test is negative. Transbronchial biopsies identify noncaseating granulomas and no evidence of infectious or malignant processes.
Which one of the following evaluations is appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sarcoid arthropathy can affect the small joints of the hands and feet. Routine radiography of the extremities is not indicated in asymptomatic patients.

B) CORRECT:

Granulomas in the lung and the skin, in the absence of other explanations, suggest the presence of sarcoidosis. Violaceous patches on the nose are a characteristic cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis called “lupus pernio.” Because sarcoidosis also frequently affects the eyes, patients diagnosed with sarcoidosis should have an initial ophthalmologic evaluation; ocular inflammation can be asymptomatic and still cause damage.

In individuals diagnosed with sarcoidosis in whom extrapulmonary disease is not suspected on the basis of symptoms or other findings, the initial evaluation should include:

• Pulmonary function testing
• Ophthalmologic examination
• Electrocardiography to screen for cardiac sarcoidosis
• A serum creatinine level to screen for renal sarcoidosis
• A serum alkaline phosphatase level to screen for liver sarcoidosis
• A serum calcium level to screen for hypercalcemia
• A complete blood count to screen for hematologic abnormalities

Routine imaging outside the chest (whole-body positron emission tomography, CT of the abdomen, or MRI of the brain) is not recommended for patients with sarcoidosis who lack symptoms that suggest involvement of the brain or abdominal organs.

Key learning point: The recommended tests for a patient with a new diagnosis of sarcoidosis include an electrocardiogram; pulmonary function testing; complete blood count; serum levels of creatinine, calcium, and alkaline phosphatase; and an ophthalmologic examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine imaging outside the chest (whole-body positron emission tomography, CT of the abdomen, or MRI of the brain) is not recommended for patients with sarcoidosis who lack symptoms that suggest involvement of the brain or abdominal organs.

D) INCORRECT:

Routine imaging outside the chest (whole-body positron emission tomography, CT of the abdomen, or MRI of the brain) is not recommended for patients with sarcoidosis who lack symptoms that suggest involvement of the brain or abdominal organs.

E) INCORRECT:

Routine imaging outside the chest (whole-body positron emission tomography, CT of the abdomen, or MRI of the brain) is not recommended for patients with sarcoidosis who lack symptoms that suggest involvement of the brain or abdominal organs.

A chest radiograph demonstrates bilateral reticular opacities with evidence of volume loss.
Nephrocalcinosis is incidentally noted in both kidneys.
